header.title: THE BLACK LODGE OF SANTA CRUZ
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occult Memoir, Practical Magic, Enochian Magic
keywords: Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram

central_thesis: This memoir details the author's intense and often tumultuous journey within the Caliphate Ordo Templi Orientis and a clandestine initiatory group, the 'Black Lodge of Santa Cruz.' It serves as a critique of established occult hierarchies and dogma, advocating for direct, experimental, and personally-tailored magical practice—especially Enochian magic—as a path to self-realization, confronting one's true will, and engaging in 'magical warfare' against perceived opposition, ultimately leading to profound personal upheaval and a rejection of institutionalized spiritual authority in favor of a primordial magical current.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter I: Initial Immersion in Thelema Lodge
structure_content.summary: The author recounts his initial engagement with the Caliphate Ordo Templi Orientis via Thelema Lodge in 1988, driven by a desire to find 'true initiates.' He describes the Lodge's environment, its Gnostic Mass, and introduces David Richard Jones (Fr Spartacus), who becomes a central figure in his exploration of Enochian magic. This chapter sets the stage for the author's growing disillusionment with O.T.O. politics.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II: Early Enochian Practice and Skepticism
structure_content.summary: The author details his and Susan's foundational magical practices, including the Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram and Liber Resh. Under Jones's guidance, they delve into Enochian magic, with Susan as skryer and the author as ceremonialist, experiencing early successes with Watchtower workings. The author begins to question the A..A.. curriculum and recounts the first 'Enochian D&D' session in Santa Cruz, a pivotal moment in the formation of the nascent 'Black Lodge.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter III: Escalation and Internal Conflicts
structure_content.summary: The author describes his deepening involvement in the Ecclesia Gnostica Catholica, becoming Priest and Priestess. He highlights the impact of Laura Chandler on David Jones. The success of the Santa Cruz workings leads to political envy, exemplified by Mordecai Shapiro's ill-fated Goëtic evocation attempt. This period marks increasing internal O.T.O. conflicts and reforms to the Gnostic Mass that curb ritualistic freedom.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IV: Lodge Raid and Personal Disintegration
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the aftermath of internal disputes, including Jim Graeb's banishment and a police raid on Thelema Lodge. The author connects these events to a chain of magical and personal misfortunes, including a notice to vacate his apartment and the Loma Prieta earthquake. He reflects on his increasing skepticism regarding established magical traditions, particularly Golden Dawn's Enochian interpretations, leading to a profound personal crisis and the beginnings of a separation from Susan.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter V: The Æthyr 'Hell Ride' and Confrontation
structure_content.summary: The narrative focuses on a challenging group working to open the 19th Æthyr, described as a 'hell ride.' The author and his associates employ precise astronomical calculations for planetary banishings. The session devolves into chaos and perceived 'possession,' culminating in a physical and emotional breakdown of the participants and a critical confrontation with Golding and Holden, who attempt to 'close down' the working against Jones's and the author's will.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VI: The 'Black Lodge' Takes Form and Seeks Legitimacy
structure_content.summary: Following the Orinda working, the perceived 'schism' and 'bifurcation' intensify. David Jones struggles with retrieving his belongings from the Lodge amidst political tensions. A significant meeting with Professor Ralph Abraham, a mathematician interested in John Dee, leads to academic recognition and the formal relocation of the CES to Santa Cruz, establishing the 'Black Lodge' as an independent entity. This move also highlights concerns regarding other occult organizations' views on Enochian magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VII: Further 'Magical Warfare' and Episcopal Ordinations
structure_content.summary: The author describes the complete breakdown of Thelema Lodge and the increasing isolation of the 'Black Lodge' group. They achieve a successful re-opening of the 19th Æthyr, solidifying their independence. David Jones initiates a 'heresy' by ordaining new Bishops (including the author and Anne) in the Gnostic Catholic Church, leveraging a hidden Crowleyan secret about O.T.O. grades. This act solidifies their break from traditional hierarchies and triggers sustained 'magical warfare' and 'interference.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VIII: The Fall of a Hero and Personal Betrayal
structure_content.summary: David Jones's mental state deteriorates under continuous stress and his obsession with reclaiming his library. The author continues intensive banishing rituals, adopting 'CHAOS' and 'BABALON' godnames to combat ongoing attacks. Jones eventually urges the author to cease the workings, fearing destruction. This results in the author's profound personal 'disintegration' and the painful realization that his hero, David Jones, ultimately prioritizes O.T.O. oaths over personal loyalty, leading to a sense of betrayal and the eventual collapse of his relationship with Susan.

The author recounts a period of homelessness and deep emotional turmoil after Susan's departure. He describes his continued, less structured magical work with Jones, relying on the I Ching for guidance. April becomes a crucial source of support and friendship during this time of profound loss. This chapter delves into the complexities of personal relationships amidst intense magical practice and the devastating consequences of the magical warfare.

The author reflects on his experiences, the loss of his 'hero' David Jones, and the dissolution of his magical community. He describes his journey back east and the slow process of healing and self-recovery, facilitated by April's unwavering support. The chapter culminates in the author's ultimate realization that true magical attainment and enlightenment come from within, independent of external hierarchies or organizations, serving as a profound lesson in personal responsibility and the nature of genuine self-discovery.

key_concepts.definition: The established magical order, which the author initially joins but increasingly critiques for its internal politics, infighting, and dogmatic adherence to institutional authority over direct magical experience.

The 'Mother Lodge' of the Caliphate O.T.O. in Oakland, serving as a hub for Gnostic Mass and occult education, but also a crucible for internal power struggles and a symbol of the institutionalized magic that the 'Black Lodge' sought to transcend.

A clandestine, experimental initiatory group formed by David Jones and the author, dedicated to practicing Enochian magic liberated from the perceived constraints and dogmas of the mainstream O.T.O. and Golden Dawn traditions.

A complex system of magic based on the visions of John Dee and Edward Kelly, central to the practical work of the 'Black Lodge.' It involves scrying into crystal spheres to access and interact with the spiritual hierarchy of the Æthyrs and their Governors.

In Enochian magic, these are 30 hierarchical spiritual 'Airs' or 'planes' that serve as fields of consciousness, each ruled by specific Governors. The practice involves ceremonial scrying to explore and draw insights from these realms, often leading to intense psychological and spiritual experiences.
A highly intricate magical seal from John Dee's system, which the author and Jones construct and utilize as a central tool in their Enochian workings, sometimes in the form of beeswax disks.

A magical current representing a return to primordial magical origins, specifically by adopting the original godnames of CHAOS and BABALON (as found in early versions of Crowley's Star Ruby ritual) for banishing rituals, thereby rejecting later Thelemic dogmatic revisions like NUIT/HADIT/THERION.

The intense experience of spiritual and psychological opposition, perceived as active interference from external entities or individuals within rival occult factions, directly impacting the practitioners' lives and magical operations, leading to defensive 'scorched earth' banishing campaigns.

A term used to describe a renegade figure, like David Jones, who, operating outside official hierarchical approval, utilizes his episcopal office to ordain others (e.g., the author and Anne) into the Gnostic Catholic Church, challenging the established O.T.O. rules and norms for succession and authority.

A Qabalistic concept referring to a great chasm or void, here experienced as a boundary or realm of dissolution, both personally and magically, encountered during intense Æthyr workings where one faces the potential fragmentation of self and the loss of one's known reality.

practical_system.description: The practical system detailed is an evolving, experimental approach to Enochian Magic, initially drawing from but ultimately diverging from traditional Golden Dawn and Thelemic structures. It emphasizes direct experience, personal will, and adaptation over rigid dogma. The author and David Jones develop methods for accessing and interacting with Æthyrs and their Governors, which evolve from 'square workings' to more astronomically precise techniques for planetary operations. This system becomes a tool for 'magical warfare' against perceived opposition, culminating in the adoption of primordial godnames (CHAOS/BABALON) for banishing rituals, signifying a radical rejection of established Thelemic dogma in favor of a direct, non-institutionalized magical current, aimed at achieving self-realization and navigating intense psychic and emotional landscapes.
tools: Holy Table / Mysterious Seven-fold Table (Sigillum Dei Æmeth, carved and beeswax disks)
rituals: Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram (LBRP)
Planetary Banishing and Invocation (astronomically precise, evolving from Hebrew godnames to CHAOS/BABALON)
Star Ruby (Crowley's Thelemic and original CHAOS/BABALON forms)
Goëtic Evocation (Bael, Furcas, including trance mediumship)
'The Vision and the Voice thereof' (recitation for Æthyr work)

relevant_quotes.text: “Jacques de Molay was not roasted alive so we could put a Holy King on the throne."
RITE, n. A religious or semi-religious ceremony fixed by law, precept or custom, with the essential oil of sincerity carefully squeezed out of it. AMBROSE BIERCE, THE DEVIL'S DICTIONARY

The student, if he attains any success in the following practices, will find himself confronted by things (ideas or beings) too glorious or too dreadful to be described. It is essential that he remain the master of all that he beholds, hears, or conceives; otherwise he will be the slave of illusion and the prey of madness. ALEISTER CROWLEY, LIBER O VEL MANUS ET SAGITTÆ

My criticism of this part of the GD work is: (First) that it emanated so largely from Kelly; (Second) That the tablets are part of a rigmarole by which Kelly persuaded Dee that they two were to be the puppet-masters of a new European political order which should supersede the kingdoms then reigning; (Third) That the same angel who dictated the Tablets also required that Kelly and Dee should have all things in common, including their wives; (Fourth) That the whole project came to the same ignominious end that is to be expected of human undertakings based upon the promises of spirits; (Fifth) That there is no good reason to suppose that Kelly and Dee, or their enterprise, to say nothing of their magic, correspond to anything Rosicrucian; (Six, and most important) That I have personal knowledge of more than twenty-five instances where the performance of magical operations based on Order formulae led to serious disintegrations of mind or body... Perhaps the most conspicuous example of the unfortunate consequences of the use of these formulas is Aleister Crowley himself; but there are plenty of others. . . PAUL FOSTER CASE, LETTER TO ISRAEL REGARDIE, 10 AUGUST 1933
The fire of God is fallen from heaven, and hath burned up the sheep, and the servants, and consumed them; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee. JOB 1:16

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides a uniquely candid and deeply personal account of modern occult practice within a specific American O.T.O. subculture of the late 1980s and early 1990s. Its relevance lies in offering an unfiltered, 'behind-the-scenes' perspective on the challenges, politics, and psychological impact of intensive ritual magic, particularly Enochian workings undertaken outside of rigidly defined institutional frameworks. It critically examines the limitations and dogmas of established occult hierarchies (O.T.O., Golden Dawn) and highlights the practical and personal risks associated with direct, experimental engagement with powerful magical currents. The author's journey into 'magical warfare' and the adoption of the '156 current' with Chaos/Babalon godnames contributes significantly to understanding the intersection of personal will, magical practice, and the broader evolutionary trends within Western Esotericism, including aspects that resonate with Chaos Magic philosophies.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is best suited for experienced practitioners and serious academic students of Western Esotericism, particularly those with a background in Enochian Magic, the history of the O.T.O., Golden Dawn studies, and Chaos Magic. It would also appeal to readers interested in autobiographical narratives of intense spiritual and magical paths and those critically examining hierarchical structures within occult organizations. Due to its graphic descriptions of personal and magical upheaval, it is not recommended for beginners seeking a general introduction to magic.
